Before him rises the great shining glass palace, jagged and angular, clear crystal 
fogged and smeared with sweat and grease and breathy condensation, but still 
its denizens can be seen by the masses of the starving that crowd around the 
edges. They cannot help but look inside, begging and weeping and hissing and 
falling as they wait for somebody, anybody, to stop the things that kill them. 
[Door opens and closes, outside sounds disappear] 
[In the distance, distorted gleeful laughs while old-time dancehall 
music plays] 
[Footsteps as the Minister continues, getting closer to the laughter] 

The Magnus Archives – MAG 189 – Peers 
 
14 
ARCHIVIST (CONT’D) 
The minister uses the back entrance; the stale and humid air hits him 
immediately, the light from the not-a-sun reflected through a dozen layers of 
glass. 
[A slap of gore] 
ARCHIVIST (CONT’D) 
The light takes on a crimson tinge as he passes an office dried with gore, and 
turns away from a back room where three men in fine suits laugh among 
themselves as they weave their pile of nooses. 
[Distorted laughs and music clear] 
[In the distance muffled yells and screams] 
ARCHIVIST (CONT’D) 
Time was, the minister thinks, they’d have at least put up a curtain, a token 
effort to hide their intentions. But now they work in full view, unafraid of what 
the masses outside may see. Their lies are just as transparent; there is no 
choice here but to believe. 
[The Minister stops walking] 
[Laughter and music has faded away; muffled yells and screams are 
louder] 
ARCHIVIST (CONT’D) 
Finally, he reaches the chamber, the heart of the wretched place. Though the 
corridors are hard to navigate in this place of clear walls, you can always follow 
the sound of blustered roaring, echoing down the way. It gets louder and 

The Magnus Archives – MAG 189 – Peers

louder with each step, until the minister crosses the threshold into the great 
room, and it swallows him whole. 
[Door clicks open and the clamouring becomes clear and loud, a 
rowdy debate chamber, an indistinct rabble] 
ARCHIVIST (CONT’D) 
The two sides scream and hoot and holler at each other, each on their end of 
the pit of sand, the arena in which they fight. The minister ignores the cobwebs 
in it as he makes his way to his chair. It is politer not to mention the thick layer 
of dust that has accumulated on the arena floor. 
[Footsteps, then leather seat creak] 
ARCHIVIST (CONT’D) 
He takes his place, marvelling again at how comfortable the seat is, how well it 
seems to fit, before the memory of the eyes outside, the knowledge that he 
can still be seen, wipes the contented smile from his face with a jerk. He looks 
across the divide at his opponents: pale and gurning things that smirk and 
guffaw and howl. They are content and safe and happy in this place, and only 
scream so loud from sheer hatred of the idea that any might make noise 
except themselves. On their thighs can be seen the glint of gold from the great 
polished nails they have driven through their legs and into the chairs, 
gangrenous wounds that ensure they shall never have to rise again, their 
position utterly secure.

tone and pitch are such as to merge seamlessly with the others. There are no
